Making a Solar Dehydrator. â˜€ï¸
Permaculture Internship week 6.

Making a large dehydrator to dry the fruits, vegetables and herbs on the farm! 
This was made our of about 90% reclaimed building materials - minus the flyscreen and screws. 
We created a solar collector to harness the energy of the sun, and our own little drying racks, so that this summer and autumn we may collect the bounty and preserve it for the winter- using only the energy of the sun - no wires, no batteries... No coal! 
Appropriate technology is so important in this time, as we seek ways to rely less on fossil fuels, so we may lessen the impacts of climate change. 
Taught by Murray Goodchild of PEACE Farm in the Yarra Valley. 
Hosted and managed by The Perma Pixie.

conversation.media_share_caption:
The bending of light, as measured by a refractometer in food substances is scaled into a reading known as Brix.
Brix is an indicator of how much dissolved solid is in the substance including sugars, amino acids, vitamins, minerals and plant hormones. In short it is an indicator of how strong and pest resistant a plant will be and, importantly for us, how flavourful our food will be.
Flavour then, vis a vis, is an indicator of how nutrition rich the food is. We all enjoy real tasting flavourful fruits and vegetables instead of the bland and insipid flavour it usually is from the supermarket.
Well, now you know that flavour corresponds with the vitamin and mineral content of a food as the latter are locked up in the sugar/starch/cellulose complexes in the plant.
When you are eating conventionally grown foods, laced with pesticides grown in nutritionally poor and dying soils, bred and artificially fed for size, water content for weight, robustness for global travel and picked unripe to survive the journey, is it any wonder these foods donâ€™t taste that great?  Itâ€™s no wonder we want to cook or process the little remaining vitality out of them and add fats, sugar, salt, and spices to give us any taste satisfaction. Without having access to a movable tunnel, the best method to transition from summer to fall/winter crops is to perform it in stages. For instance, the center beds of the high tunnel may still have productive trellised tomatoes in September, whereas the edge beds may have grown an earlier crop of cucumbers or summer squash now at the end of the productive phase. â €
â €
For an unheated or â€˜Coldâ€™ tunnel, these former cucumber/squash beds would be selected to be re-planted with the longer maturing fall/winter crops such as fresh winter carrots, kale, chard, scallions, or even direct seeded with a fall crop of spinach. Then, once the tomatoes have finished producing at the beginning of October, the empty beds can be direct seeded with faster maturing salad greens like baby leaf lettuce or transplanted with two-week old spinach seedlings. â €
â €
With the additional protection of an inner row cover over low tunnel hoops, these crops would then be harvestable around the end of November and then weekly throughout the winter depending on the severity of the weather conditions and its effect on regrowth for â€˜cut-and-come-againâ€™ crops.â €

The bending of light, as measured by a refractometer in food substances is scaled into a reading known as Brix.
Brix is an indicator of how much dissolved solid is in the substance including sugars, amino acids, vitamins, minerals and plant hormones. In short it is an indicator of how strong and pest resistant a plant will be and, importantly for us, how flavourful our food will be.
Flavour then, vis a vis, is an indicator of how nutrition rich the food is. We all enjoy real tasting flavourful fruits and vegetables instead of the bland and insipid flavour it usually is from the supermarket.
Well, now you know that flavour corresponds with the vitamin and mineral content of a food as the latter are locked up in the sugar/starch/cellulose complexes in the plant.
When you are eating conventionally grown foods, laced with pesticides grown in nutritionally poor and dying soils, bred and artificially fed for size, water content for weight, robustness for global travel and picked unripe to survive the journey, is it any wonder these foods donâ€™t taste that great?  Itâ€™s no wonder we want to cook or process the little remaining vitality out of them and add fats, sugar, salt, and spices to give us any taste satisfaction. But we arenâ€™t getting any real nutritional satisfaction either.
When you eat foods, particularly homegrown, in well-built soils, free of poisonous influences, you taste the difference. You feel the difference inside of you if you pay attention. When you discover and experience this for yourself and realize that not only are you depriving your taste buds of any real adventure, but your body and brain of real nutrition too, you stop compromising on quality.
We pump foods up on water for weight with artificial fertilizer salts for commerce...for profit...not for health. As Geoff Lawton said, â€œIf our food was valued by its refractive index and not by weight, how we all grew it would change very quickly across the planet.â€ Such practices donâ€™t feed the soil so they canâ€™t feed your plants, which in turn canâ€™t feed you. How much longer will you deprive yourself of high-quality nutrition? How much do you think you are worth it? Post credit: @permaculture

Let me try to impart as much house plant insight as I can with this one time lapse:
â–ªï¸Soil aeration: you water your plants because it doesn't rain inside your house. You should therefore aerate the soil occasionally because there are no worms inside your house plant soil. Soil structure matters! (more on this in the link in my profile)
â–ªï¸Soil drainage and saturation: see how "excess" water escapes from being absorbed by the soil as it pools into the dish below. But as the video speeds up - notice how that pool is sucked up into the soil. Thus, the soil was not yet at saturation because it had the capacity to take in more water - was no excess water here. For most tropical foliage plants, when they need water, you should bring the soil to saturation. Think of the jungle: "when it rains, it pours!"
â–ªï¸Afraid of overwatering? I know you thought of this after reading the previous point. If you did, you probably also think that soil just "dries out" in a passive manner. Fact: the majority of the soil becomes dry because the plant uses up the moisture - evaporation only affects the top inch of soil. The plant only takes in the water deeper in the soil when it is photosynthesizing in the right light. So, the counter example is this: if you put your plant in a decorative position that is far from any windows or has a limited view of the sky, it will not be photosynthesizing as quickly, which means the soil will stay moist for longer, which increases the risk of root rot.
~
~

Video by @bertiegregory. What do you do if you're a capybara and a jaguar is coming for you? JUUUUUUUMP! Caiman aren't the jaguar's only prey in the Pantanal, Brazil. The world's largest rodent, the capybara, is also near the top of the menu. But looking like a giant ginea pig, you might think they're sitting ducks. Far from it. Capybara are on constant alert and are never far from their emergency exit- the river. Whenever they sense danger, they let out a loud bark (to alert their family group) before launching in! Stay tuned for our new jaguar show for @natgeowild premiering later this year. Shot for @stevewinterphoto and @natgeo. Follow @bertiegregory for more wildlife adventures.

conversation.media_share_caption: Sealed grow room climate control is simply heat transfer. Sensible cooling counteracts heat gain (lights, motors, DH) and latent cooling removes humidity. The objective is to minimize energy used to accomplish desired room temperature and relative humidity. When air is cooled, relative humidity goes up. The more air is cooled, the higher relative humidity goes. If cooled enough (below dewpoint), water condenses and falls out of the air. Air conditioners cool room air by about 15 to 20Â°F. In damp rooms (80% RH) lots of water condenses and air-conditioners provide both heat and water removal. Humidifiers are needed to maintain high humidity during lights-on. A thin (two row) evaporator coil in the air handler would remove less water, providing a higher SHR (sensible heat ratio). This would reduce the need for humidifiers. In dry rooms (50% RH) little water is condensed by air conditioners. Dry room air must be cooled a full 20Â° before condensing begins to occur. The air-conditioner now delivers mainly sensible cooling, all temperature drop and little humidity removal. Plants are still transpiring so dehumidifiers are needed to remove the moisture. Stand alone (plug-in) dehumidifiers have cooling coils and a compressor built into one cabinet. As one coil cools room air to condense water, a second coil rejects heat developed by the compressor. The result yields warm, dry air. During lights-on additional air-conditioning and energy use is needed to remove dehumidifier heat. At night, some heat is needed to counteract transpirational cooling. Each pint of water transpired creates 1000 BTUs of cooling to the plant. If 20 pints transpire in one hour, 20,000 BTUs of heat must be added to the room to maintain steady temperature.

This was an amazing and challenging project beginning during a heat wave in September as the days grew shorter and cold into fall. A tough decision was what lumber to use. REPOST!! Thanks to @growru for the detailed post. REPOST: growruOverview:
Here is a quick rundown on how to take a sap sample and then check the brix and ph of the plant sap. You can use ph test strips or a horiba la aqua ph pen to test a few drops of sap. Horiba also makes meters for Ca, K, N03, Na, EC that way can take samples and do testing in the field or gh. In an ideal situation we would send samples to a lab and get an analysis on all the elements. But since this is not available everywhere for now for cannabis we can use handheld meters. Sap press, paper ph test strips and Refractometer is the bare minimum to get started for the least cost. Next up, I would get the ph, then potassium meter and then optionally calcium, sodium and nitrate.

How:
Get a piece of paper and a pen. 
Note the time and date. I then take a lower and upper leaf sample. Take the test at the same time every day. A few hours after sunup or lights on. 
1. All the tools lined up. Top is vice grips, then there is a ph, calcium and potassium and bottom is refractometer, which is used to test brix. 
2. Take a leaf. Remove petiole.
3. Put into vice grips for pressing sap. 
4. Squeeze sap into a horiba ph meter. Take reading. Continue for Ca, K, etc if you got those. Dont worry if you dont, ph and brix is good for now.
5. Pour that sap into the refractometer, hold up to the light and then take the brix reading.

Note your measurements for lower and upper leaves. 
Low pH + Moderate Brix = Calcium Deficiency
Low pH + Low Brix = Potassium Deficiency
6.4 pH + High Brix = Balance

Above 12 is considered High Brix. 
Generally, the more mature leaves on the plant will give the most accurate picture of the plantâ€™s health, level of resistance or susceptibility to problems. Since the plant spends most of its energy supporting new growth, the pH of new leaves will not reflect the pH of the rest of the plant as a whole. Sap and brix test can also be used to test the plant response of a mineral or microbial application. 
Want to learn more via one on one training for you and or your team? Hit me up via DM or email lead@growru.com to setup a training session.

FOLLOWUP: On Saturday I posed the question here on IG asking you to spot the differences and identify the â€œknockoffâ€. The answers were all over the place, many were wrong but itâ€™s not so much that they were incorrect but how enthusiastic and passionate so many of the incorrect answers were. Either way, hereâ€™s the answer and as promised Iâ€™ll give my $0.02 as to why it might matter to anyone working with Uponor tubing .
.

This is about @uponorna and Sioux Chief. Not any other brand or system. And itâ€™s just me talking about it, no one is paying me for this, I just hope itâ€™s helpful .
.

The bottom, thinner-walled fitting with the more dramatic â€œbarbâ€ is from Uponor. The top fitting is relatively new to the market and sold through retail outlets and some supply houses. Both are made from and engineered polymer. If you want technical specs on either just visit the respective websites .
.

I cannot comment on whether one is â€œbetterâ€ than the other. I can say without a doubt that mixing the two severely effects the Uponor warranty coverage, but it does not immediately void the warranty as a lot of people in the industry think and often say .
.

Uponorâ€™s warranty (partially included, swipe) is as a â€œsystemâ€ 25 years. Sioux chiefâ€™s warranty is less explicit in what I have found available online but is also 25 years.  Uponor clearly states that a â€œsystemâ€ constitutes the use of only Uponor branded tubing, fittings and components. As soon as a component of another manufacturer is installed the warranty coverage period is significantly less .
.

So why does this matter? If youâ€™re selling the product as one thatâ€™s covered for 25 years from the manufacturer but you use non-Uponor products in that system, youâ€™re likely liable for repairs at some point and will not have the support you could have. Itâ€™s my opinion that the relatively small amount of possible savings from using a lower cost fitting now is unimportant. Itâ€™s also important to know if the product youâ€™re buying is going to negate warranty period coverage and sold otherwise. I think itâ€™s important to do your homework and know what youâ€™re buying and offering. Hope this helps ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¼ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¼ğŸ’¯ #plumbing #sharetheknowledge

This might not look like much to anyone who doesnâ€™t regularly work with PEX tubing but to me itâ€™s somewhat significant .

Quiet a few years ago I made the switch to a major brand PEX-a product after years of installing another major brand PEX-b tubing system. Both are great but one is superior in just a few key ways .

First I believe the cold expansion fitting system is better. There are fewer opportunities to make mistakes. Second is the ability to repair damaged tubing (i.e. kink in the line) without the need for fittings. That last one is great because itâ€™s not only a less expensive repair but can be done anywhere on the tubing, even if the tubing will be embedded in concrete (radiant system) .

The other part of this pic that gets me going is the fact we can make this type of repair with a cordless tool. The cordless heat gun isnâ€™t a niche tool, itâ€™s very useful for many different applications. As long as you know itâ€™s limits itâ€™s seriously handy to have in the arsenal. I wonder why other companies havenâ€™t followed up with their own cordless heat gun? I love this thing! .

This is how we cut our bow ties:
1) trace your bow tie onto the work piece.
2) scribe the line with a knife to eliminate tear out and to make the chisel work at the end easier.
3) drill a hole so you have a place to start routing.
4) use the router to clean up 90% of the cut out.
5) use a chisel to clean up the last 10%.
Would love to hear your thoughts/ideas/suggestions on this process.

EN: I'll leave it here. The next (successful for me) attempt to make a "sliding power junction" of the profile to the profile / surface at a right angle. The resulting console, almost 450 mm long, shows a deflection of 5 mm at its end, under a uniform load of almost 35 kg. Compared with the previous version, a perforated fastener with a metal thickness of 2.5 mm was used (for the previously used material, the declared thickness was 2 mm (in fact, 1.85 .... 1.9 mm)). In the process of manufacturing this specimen, new ideas and options have appeared that will improve this product.
P.s. this, so far, a prototype, so zinc plating with zinc did not conduct it. Of course, it will.

Fun little project that got thrown my way.  This is a 6 ton hex unit (essentially a small chiller that ties into a Mitsubishi City Multi VRF System) that is cooling a glycol loop.  The glycol loop accepts heat from the elevator equipment oil.  It has a buffer tank to prevent temperature swings and to give the loop extra capacity.  The glycol loop is run in boiler pex and it's layed out in a primary/secondary fashion.  Got some help from one our awesome plumbers with running the loop. Glad to have this one in the history books.  #hvac #hvactech #technician #hvaclife #vrf #mitsubishi #heatpump #chiller #pump #pex #lovewhatyoudo #lovewhatido

#sundayboilerschool Brief summary of a Spirovent. Noisy pipes, valves, and other air-related noises are often accepted as the signs of a functioning system. Excessive pump noise, cavitation, and cascading in terminal units are considered normal. Air in system water can cause corrosion, reduced efficiency, poorly heated rooms, accelerated component wear and on-going complaints. Unlike conventional air eliminators or air scoops, the Spirovent completely eliminates 100% of the free air, 100% of the entrained air, and up to 99.6% of the dissolved air in the system. Consisting of woven copper wire soldered to a copper tube, the patented SpirotubeÂ® creates a low velocity area in the Spirovent that scrubs the bubbles from the water. The air bubbles rise and collect in the air chamber before they are vented from the system via an integral automatic valve. Ideal placement of the Spirovent is based on microbubble separation and Henryâ€™s Law*. Simply put, Henryâ€™s Law states that air is released from water as the temperature increases or the pressure decreases. In hydronic heating systems, the Spirovent should be installed in the boiler supply line where the temperature is highest. Should the circulator be located on the supply line as well, the Spirovent should be installed between the boiler and the circulator.

I miss the big jobs, hiding from the wind. 15 inch stacks, frozen toes pulling them into shafts. Bandsaw blades splitting in the middle of cutting 3/4 inch rod. Forced to remove your gloves the get your nuts started. 
But then I remember the GCs. Too many managers trying to figure out how to build a building with no labor. 
How is that possible? It's a new method, very popular. Contractors pay their worker to get the building built, forwards backwards however the book worms want it done, who never consider weather and other unavoidable obstacles. Then the contractors go to the "management" company for their money, but the management doesn't pay. Instead they put their resources into the courts to figure out every way to nickle and dime the contractors out of the money that is owed. 
Still we show up, frozen toed, and we build your buildings. Never forget how this country grows. 
Remember that every time you walk into a warm building. Enjoy the fruits of our labor.

To cut down on the need for excess refrigeration at the farm stand we stick to warm season crops that keep at ambient temperatures. This also helps cut down on vegetables and fruits that require a lot of time with prep before sale. ğŸ…
.
The list includes heritage non-GMO popping corn, winter squash, dried beans, potatoes, tomatoes, cucumbers, peppers, and summer squash. ğŸ˜‹
.
These plants also lend themselves to fantastic permaculture set-ups on the farm. We utilize companion planting to the max to help plants carve out their ideal growing environment. The three sisters garden is the best example. ğŸ¤“
.
Corn, the first sister, is planted in blocks about 20x20'. We do both dent corn and popping corn. The Oaxacan variety from @bakercreekseeds has done exceptionally well on our land, so we keep planting it for cornmeal and treating our hens. We are trying a heritage black and strawberry popcorn this year from @seed_savers_exchange and are excited to see how it does. ğŸŒ½
.
Then winter squash, the second sister, is planted along the perimeter. The squash's big leaves shade the soil to slow the loss of moisture, so thirsty corn gets enough water and keeps weeds at bay. ğŸƒ .
Finally, the third sister is pole beans, which we plant at the base of every corn stalk once it hits 1â€™ tall. The beans climb the corn stalks for support and in turn act as nitrogen fixers, fertilizing our soil for free. â¬
.
Come September, we will be swimming in crops that store through the winter like total champs. Dried beans for chilis and stews, popcorn for late night munching, and all kinds of winter squash for wholesome cold weather meals. ğŸ¥˜
.
Does anybody else try three sisters gardens on their farm? How has it worked out for you? â€”@kelseyjorissen
.

Video by @bertiegregory. What do you do if you're a capybara and a jaguar is coming for you? JUUUUUUUMP! Caiman aren't the jaguar's only prey in the Pantanal, Brazil. The world's largest rodent, the capybara, is also near the top of the menu. But looking like a giant ginea pig, you might think they're sitting ducks. Far from it. Capybara are on constant alert and are never far from their emergency exit- the river. Whenever they sense danger, they let out a loud bark (to alert their family group) before launching in! Stay tuned for our new jaguar show for @natgeowild premiering later this year. Shot for @stevewinterphoto and @natgeo. Follow @bertiegregory for more wildlife adventures.
